body:
When a developer is examining `debug.log` after something goes wrong, it's often useful to know the exact options the failing instance of `bitcoind` was started with. Sometimes the `debug.log` file is all that's available for the analysis.

This PR logs the `bitcoin.conf` entries and command-line arguments to `debug.log` on startup. Here's an example. I created `bitcoin.conf` as follows:
```
debug=xxx
debug=yyy
```
and then started `bitcoind` built from this branch:
```
$ bitcoind --debug=cmdline1 --debug=cmdline2
```
and the following appeared early in `debug.log`
```
(...)
2019-05-29T03:31:10Z Using RdRand as an additional entropy source
2019-05-29T03:31:10Z Default data directory /home/larry/.bitcoin
2019-05-29T03:31:10Z Using data directory /home/larry/.bitcoin
2019-05-29T03:31:10Z Config file: /home/larry/.bitcoin/bitcoin.conf
2019-05-29T03:31:10Z config-file arg:  -debug=xxx
2019-05-29T03:31:10Z config-file arg:  -debug=yyy
2019-05-29T03:31:10Z command-line arg: -debug=cmdline1
2019-05-29T03:31:10Z command-line arg: -debug=cmdline1
2019-05-29T03:31:10Z Using at most 125 automatic connections (1024 file descriptors available)
(...)
```
I don't think this will cause a security vulnerability because `debug.log` is created with file permissions that allow reading only by owner.

I don't know how to write an automated test for these changes, suggestions are welcome.
title: On bitcoind startup, write config args to debug.log
